data.title: Team Home Homewood Patriots Sports
data.meta_description: Follow the  Patriots schedule, roster, events and photos all in one place.
data.text:
*Pictured above – Eli Brooks at the Mobile Challenge of Champions

After winning both the girls’ and boys’ division at the Homewood Invitational on March 16th the Homewood Track and Field teams had a meet at Auburn on March 21st before Spring Break and then had a group of athletes invited to compete at the Mobile Challenge of Champions on Saturday, April 6th. Both teams will head to the Mountain Brook Invitational this weekend, but the Patriots will not be at full strength because of prom on Saturday.

At the Auburn Elite Meet on March 21st, the girls came in 2nd behind Auburn, and the boys came in 3rd behind Auburn and Hoover. Other teams competing included Mountain Brook, Opelika, Hewitt-Trussville, Smiths Station, and Central – Phenix City. Makiyah Sills (100m, 100mH, 300mH), Lainey Phelps (800m), Alex Brooks (Pole Vault), Aiya Finch (LJ), Maggie White (Discus), Will Stone (1600m), and Eli Brooks (PV) all had event wins against an impressive field of athletes.

The Mobile Challenge of Champions is a prestigious meet where the meet director invites a select group of athletes to compete. Most of the athletes are state champions, and teams come from all over the U.S. Homewood had 16 athletes invited and had some impressive performances. Will Stone defended his title in the 2 mile. Makiyah Sills had an outstanding meet, PR’d, and placed 2nd in both the 100m Hurdles (14.32) and the 300m Hurdles (44.56). Aiya Finch also had a solid meet and placed 3rd in both long jump and triple jump.

The Homewood Invitational was a huge success with Homewood winning both the girls’ and boys’ divisions against an impressive field. The girls won the meet with 118 points with Thompson (83), Hoover (59), Pelham (57), and Hewitt-Trussville (51) rounding out the top five. The boys won with 92.5 points and were followed by Northridge (75), Hoover (73), Vestavia Hills (65), and Oak Mountain (59). 25 full teams were invited to the meet, and individuals who met qualification standards could also enter. The highlight of the meet was the boys 3200m where 9 competitors were under 9:31. Here are Homewood’s athletes that earned medals and/or broke records on Saturday:

Makiyah Sills – 1st in 100m Hurdles, 1st in 300m Hurdles (meet record)

Aiya Finch – 1st in Triple Jump, 1st in Long Jump

Josh Thomas – 1st in Triple Jump (broke school record with a 46-10), 2nd in Long Jump, 3rd 110m Hurdles

Maggie White – 1st in Discus, 3rd in Shot Put

Lainey Phelps – 1st in 3200m (meet record)

Will Stone – 2nd in 3200m

Crawford Hope – 2nd in 1600m

Stephon May – 3rd in Long Jump

Eli Brooks – 3rd in Javelin

Walker Smith – 3rd in Pole Vault

Reid Catherine Bunn – 3rd in High Jump

Tobias Thomas – 4th in Shot Put (broke school record with a 49-6)

Girls 4x800m Relay – 3rd (Adah Allen, Edie Smith, Ellen Reidinger, Lainey Phelps)

The Homewood Patriots Track and Field teams just completed the most successful year in program history by winning the AHSAA 6A Track and Field State Championships in both the girls and boys divisions at Gulf Shores this weekend. This is the first time in program history that both the boys and girls won the indoor and outdoor championships. The girls have now won the outdoor title five years in a row, and the boys completed the Triple Crown (cross country, indoor, and outdoor championships in a single school year) . The boys also accomplished the Triple Crown in 2013-2014, and the girls did it in 2016-2017. The following is a list summarizing the meet results, including team scores, individual state champions, All-State performers (top 3), and point scorers (top 8).

Boys

Homewood 80.5

Northridge 63

Ramsay 58

Opelika 57

Oxford 35.5

Will Stone (1st in 800m, 1600m, and 3200m)

4x800m Relay 1st (Logan Justice, Brady Cassell, Jack Gray, Will Stone)

Eli Brooks (2nd Pole Vault, 5th Javelin)

Patrick McMahon (4th Discus, 8th Shot Put)

John Michael Hurry (4th Javelin)

Jaden Alexander (5th Long Jump)

Tobias Thomas (5th Shot Put)

Logan Justice (6th Pole Vault)

Boubacar Sylla (7th 110m Hurdles)

Stephon May (7th High Jump, 8th Long Jump)

Girls

Homewood 126.75

Pelham 81

Ramsay 52

Paul Bryant 47

Ft. Payne 40.75

Jasmine Griffin (1st in 100m Hurdles and 300m Hurdles, 3rd 100m)

Celie Jackson (1st 3200m, 3rd 1600m, 3rd 800m)

Christian Hill (1st Triple Jump, 2nd Long Jump)

Aiya Finch (1st Long Jump, 4th Triple Jump)

Alex Brooks (1st Pole Vault)

Makiyah Sills (3rd 100m Hurdles, 7th 100m)

Kayla Mikula (3rd Triple Jump)

Anna Grace Gibbons (3rd Pole Vault)

Briana Rapley (6th 100m Hurdles)

Victoria Thompson (7th 3200m)

Edie Smith (8th 1600m)

4x800m Relay 3rd (Adah Allen, Hanna Brook Gibbons, Edie Smith, Celie Jackson)

4x400m Relay 6th (Ariana Roper, Anna Grace Gibbons, Autumn Tate, Kiara Gooden)

The Homewood Track and Field teams have Sectionals next Friday and Saturday at Mountain Brook and head into the postseason with both teams still ranked #1 in 6A. They competed at the Mountain Brook Invitational and the Hewitt-Trussville Invitational the last two weekends. Also, the JV season ended with the JV Championships at Hewitt-Trussville.

Both the boys and girls teams finished 3rd out of 65 schools at the Mountain Brook Invitational on April 13th and 14th and were first among 6A teams. Jasmine Griffin (sprints, hurdles) led the way for the girls by winning the MVP award after scoring a total of 29 points. Other top point scorers for the girls were Makiyah Sills (20), Aiya Finch (11), Alex Brooks (10), and Briana Rapley (7). The boys were led by Will Stone with 15 points, John Michael Hurry (10), and Boubacar Sylla (8). John Michael Hurry broke the school record in javelin with a throw of 176-6.

The boys and girls teams finished 2nd out of 37 schools at the Hewitt-Trussville Invitational on Friday and Saturday. Makiyah Sills, Aiya Finch, Celie Jackson, and Alex Brooks led the girls in points scored. Stephon May, Will Stone, Boubacar Sylla, Jaden Alexander, and Tobias Thomas led the boys in points scored. Additionally, Alyssa Langford (LJ, TJ), Maddie Kline (HJ), and Anthony Fields (TJ) all won their events at the JV Championships on Thursday.

The Homewood track and field teams went to Mobile for the Challenge of Champions and had some outstanding performances. There were no team scores at these meets, but individuals performed extremely well. The invitational portion of the meet on Saturday is a national-level meet with schools from all over the United States. The following were Homewood’s top performances in the invitational division:

Aiya Finch – 1st Long Jump, 3rd Triple Jump

Will Stone – 1st 2 mile

Josh Thomas – 2nd Long Jump and Triple Jump

Jasmine Griffin – 3rd 300m Hurdles, 4th 100m

Christian Hill – 3rd Long Jump

Stephon May – 3rd High Jump

Alex Brooks – 4th Pole Vault

The open portion of the meet was on Friday night, and Homewood was led by Patrick McMahon (1st Discus) and John Michael Hurry (1st Javelin). Makiyah Sills (300m Hurdles), Anna Grace Gibbons (Pole Vault), and Jaden Alexander (Long Jump) also had outstanding meets and placed in the top 3 in their events.

The Homewood Track and Field teams had some outstanding accomplishments the two weeks before spring break at the Homewood Invitational and the Auburn Elite Meet and look to build on that momentum this weekend at the Mobile Challenge of Champions. Ten Homewood athletes have been invited to compete at the elite national-level meet on Saturday at the Mobile Challenge of Champions, and both teams are also competing in the open division Friday night. Both the boys and girls teams continue to be ranked #1 in 6A.

Here is a summary of the top performances at the Homewood Invitational, which is one of the most competitive meets in the state all season. The girls won the team competition with Hoover coming in 2nd. The boys were 4th in the team competition behind Hoover, Smiths Station, and Thompson.

Jasmine Griffin – 1st 100mH, 1st 300mH, 3rd 100m

Makiyah Sills – 2nd 100mH, 2nd 300mH, 6th 100m

Josh Thomas – 2nd LJ, 3rd TJ, 6th 110mH, 8th HJ

Aiya Finch – 1st LJ, 4th TJ

Will Stone – 1st 3200m

Lainey Phelps – 2nd 800m

Christian Hill – 3rd LJ, 3rd TJ

Patrick McMahon – 3rd Discus, 6th SP

Alex Brooks – 3rd PV

Stephon May – 4th LJ, 5th HJ

Briana Rapley – 4th 100mH, 7th 300mH

Celie Jackson – 4th 3200m

Jaden Alexander – 5th LJ

John Michael Hurry – 5th Javelin

Boubacar Sylla – 6th 300mH, 8th 110mH

Eli Brooks – 6th PV

Anna Grace Gibbons – 6th PV

Reid Catherine Bunn – 8th HJ

Kris Wilkins – 8th Discus

Girls Relays: 4x100m 1st and 4x800m 6th

Boys Relays: 4x400m and 4x800m 6th

The boys won team competition at the Auburn Elite Meet against some of the best teams in the state, and the girls were 3rd behind Auburn and Hoover. Here is a list of those who were in the top 3.

Josh Thomas – 1st LJ, 2nd TJ, 3rd HJ, 3rd 110mH

Lainey Phelps – 1st 1600m, 2nd 800m

Jasmine Griffin – 1st 300mH, 3rd 100mH

Christian Hill – 1st LJ, 3rd TJ

Alex Brooks – 1st PV (11’6″ and broke her own school record)

Reid Catherine Bunn – 1st HJ

Patrick McMahon – 1st Discus

Stephon May – 2nd HJ

Girls and Boys 4x100m – 2nd

Aiya Finch – 3rd LJ

John Michael Hurry – 3rd Javelin

Boubacar Sylla – 3rd 300mH

Will Stone – 3rd 1600m
